qas.question: What are some classical societies whose literature is still studied today?

answers.text: Ancient China, Ancient India, Persia and Ancient Greece and Rome

qas.question: Besides entertainment or informational value, classic literature also possessed what quality?

answers.text: a covert moral or didactic purpose

qas.question: What societal evolution helped to develop drama and satire by providing a ready audience?
From what settings did lyric poetry derive?
What is an example of a collection of classic Chinese lyric poetry?

answers.text: the Shijing or Book of Songs

qas.question: Literature from Ancient China, Cambodia, Ancient India, Persia and what other two societies are still studied today?

plausible_answers.text: Sanskrit Panchatantra or the Metamorphoses of Ovid.

qas.question: Two works that had either overt moral or didactic purpose are what?
What genres developed as rural culture grew and provided a larger audience?
Epic poetry was a specialty of what?
In West Asia, songs were collected by what people as poems?

plausible_answers.text: a means of transmission for speculative and philosophical literature in early civilizations

qas.question: What did academies provide when a more suburban culture developed?

plausible_answers.text: Ancient China, Ancient India, Persia and Ancient Greece and Rome

qas.question: Besides Ancient Japan, what classical societies have literature that is still studied today?
What genres developed as suburban culture provided a bigger audience?
Who collected songs as poems from West Asia?
What was epic poetry the specialty of?
What did urban culture provide that helped poetry and satire?
What were poems in East Asia collected as?
Who collected songs in Ancient Asia?

context: As a more urban culture developed, academies provided <b10_0>a means of transmission for speculative and philosophical literature in early civilizations<b10_0/>, resulting in the prevalence of literature in <a0_0><b11_0>Ancient China, Ancient India, Persia and <b5_0>Ancient Greece and Rome<b11_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>. Many works of earlier periods, even in narrative form, had <a1_0>a covert moral or didactic purpose<a1_0/>, such as the <b6_0>Sanskrit Panchatantra or the Metamorphoses of Ovid.<b6_0/> <b7_0><b12_0>Drama and satire<b12_0/><b7_0/> also developed as <a2_0>urban culture<a2_0/> provided <b15_0>a larger public audience<b15_0/>, and later readership, for literary production. Lyric poetry (as opposed to epic poetry) was often the speciality of <a3_0><b8_0><b14_0>courts and aristocratic circles<b14_0/><a3_0/>,<b8_0/> particularly in East Asia where <b16_0>songs<b16_0/> were collected by the <b9_0><b13_0><b17_0>Chinese aristocracy<b17_0/><b13_0/><b9_0/> as poems, the most notable being <a4_0>the Shijing or Book of Songs<a4_0/>. Over a long period, the poetry of popular pre-literate balladry and song interpenetrated and eventually influenced poetry in the literary medium.
